title: Turn postgres/mysql table/column comments into Rust doc comments
body:
I took a stab at implementing the easy part of #2005.

Sqlite doesn't seem to have (proper) support for table/column comments, so the functionality is added only for postgres and mysql.

As implemented the comments are always queried from the db but only written with `--with-docs`. The interaction with the autogenerated docs such that it will prefer the schema comment if one exists and use the automatic one otherwise. Might be better to make this more configurable?

I renamed `UsesInformationSchema` -> `DefaultSchema` and removed `type_column`/`type_schema` as those were only used in `get_table_data` which is no longer generic, but `default_schema` was still in use elsewhere.

I wasn't able to figure out how to make `null_if_text` more generic, but maybe it's fine to keep it simple since it's only used in one place here?

I'm still not too familiar with diesel's code so there might be some oddities in here, but hopefully this is at least in the right direction.

Instead of figuring out each spot where this be an issue I just ran the scripts through https://www.shellcheck.net/ and fixed any issues that popped up. While I was at it I also made the indentation consistent at 4 spaces. I can make a more minimal PR or one that has everything indented with 2 spaces if that's preferred though.

Vitess does not allow changing the parsing of MySQL queries themselves, and as such does not support the SQL modes "ANSI_QUOTES", "NO_BACKSLASH_ESCAPES", "PIPES_AS_CONCAT", and "REAL_AS_FLOAT"

https://github.com/vitessio/vitess/pull/10163/files#diff-9d2575386e98a47276e4d5c75e73cdefec7078a95ea4e159b50806a8c3099c1bR101

Vitess is a popular scalability layer on top of MySQL, used by default in PlanetScale, and we should support it by default (and either allow this mode to be added manually with config, or drop support for this mode)

title: Allow custom backends to overwrite `QueryFragment` impls for `SelectStatement` and `BoxedSelectStatement`
body:
This commit introduces the necessary associated type to `SqlDialect` so
that custom backends can provide custom `QueryFragment` implementations
for `SelectStatement` and `BoxedSelectStatement`. This is required as
some database systems require a different order of clauses there. (The
`firebird` backend is using a custom fork for this currently).
All existing backends in diesel will just use the existing
implementations.
In addition this commit extends the `__diesel_public_if` macro to
conditionally make struct fields public as well. As it's not possible to
apply proc-macro attributes directly to struct fields, this is solved by
having an explicit list of "public" fields in the macro call on the
struct itself. Such structs are also marked as `#[non_exhaustive]` so
that we can add additional fields later on.

See https://github.com/fernandobatels/rsfbclient/pull/127 for a possible use case

title: Fix #3252
body:
This commit fixes an issue where test transactions caused connection to
be marked as broken when returned to a r2d2 connection pool. It is a
quite common pattern to create a connection pool with 1 connection, and
call `begin_test_transaction` on the connection before putting it into
the pool. This allows users to easily test applications using connection
pools without modifying an existing schema. The recent changes to our
transaction manager implementation + our r2d2 implementation broke this
pattern.

This commit introduces an additional flag inside of the transaction
manager state, which tracks whether `begin_test_transaction` was called
or not. This flag is later used to decide whether a connection should be
considered broken or not.

In addition this commit centralises the `is_broken`  implementation as
part of the transaction manager itself + marks
`transaction_manager_status_mut` as part of the unstable public
API (this method is only useful for third party connection or
transactionmanager implementations)

title: Allow custom select expressions in `Selectable`
body:
It's is a recurring use-case that 90% of the fields of a `Selectable` struct could be selected directly, but just one of them needs a bit more complex expression.

For this use case, this commit adds support for specifying fully custom select expression at the field level when deriving `Selectable`, by specifying the `select_expression` and `select_expression_type` attributes.

e.g: 
https://github.com/diesel-rs/diesel/blob/0d6395dd74dbf5ed1c0621082a40d5544a4fd224/diesel_derives/tests/selectable.rs#L131-L135

This could probably be later improved by getting able to infer `select_expression_type` for simple cases.

title: Improve the documentation of `QueryDsl::inner_join`
body:
This commit adds some notes about the used join syntax and how this can
affect query planing on postgres based on the discussion in #3216.

Additionally it removes the restricting that the same table cannot be
joined twice. Instead we point to `diesel::alias!` now.

title: CLI: Allow running without a `down.sql` migration
body:
Some people don't like to write down migrations, as depending on your workflow, they take a lot of time to write, may be *never* used (esp. when you have CD pipelines and just reset the database from scratch when developing), and consequently are typically largely untested.

I wish to support this for those (like us) who would rather write a new `up` migration to revert unwanted changes through CI/CD if necessary.

(NB: The original issue is that since we typically wouldn't fill `down.sql`, we would have to go edit that file to add a newline for formatting everytime we create a migration, and then leave it there even though it doesn't mean anything, and we would be unsure which ones were properly filled and which ones weren't.)

title: Return the original error when rollback attempt fails for `BrokenTransactionManager`
body:
Small follow-up on #3211 after some usage :)

This may happen when connection breaks from within a transaction function.
In this case, we are more interested in the inner error, which probably
explains why the connection broke.

I have also considered an alternate design where the rollback function
would return `Ok(())` when transaction manager is broken, which would
have had the same effect while easing things for users using the
begin/commit/rollback functions directly instead of using the `transaction`
functions, but at the same time that would have been super weird to have
rollback return `Ok` when transaction manager/connection is broken.
That being said I have no strong preference for either design.

title: More straightforward transaction error handling
body:
**Changes commit error strategy:**
 - Errors on commit will be returned directly, *unless* rollback is attempted and fails.
 - In that case, `Error::RollbackErrorOnCommit` will contain both errors. (`RollbackError` and `CommitTransactionFailed` variants are removed, and typical rollback errors are otherwise returned unpacked)
 - `BrokenTransaction` error is renamed to `BrokenTransactionManager`, as this is in effect when it is triggered, and "BrokenTransaction" could be confused with "top-level rollback necessary", which is a different concept.

This design stems from noticing that:
 - End-user having to match on original error as well as possibly
   recursively `CommitError` containing what they are looking for
   (typically, a possible serialization failure) is a hassle.
 - Rollback errors are far less common than commit errors, and typically
   result in abandonning to use this connection ever again, so it's fine
   if getting the details about those is a bit more complex.
 - It is still possible for the user to differentiate commit errors from
   in-closure errors if really necessary (backtrace will be properly
   collected, and user has control over the closure so they can check)

This allows for easier handling of e.g. serialization failures.

**Changes transaction error handling strategy:**
- Instead of providing API for custom error handling on commit, connection is free to register updates to the transaction manager status as it encounters errors.
- This transaction manager status is updated to be able to store that transaction is aborted and requires top-level rollback to be usable again.
- This information is used in `AnsiTransactionManager`'s commit/rollback logic. Notably, if top-level transaction is detected to be broken, the transaction manager will not even attempt rollback of savepoints.

This design seems to simplify error handling (number of lines goes down), while removing some mysql-specific code from the general `AnsiTransactionManager` and still allowing proper transaction depth tracking. (The tests updates mostly relate to the first part, about not packing rollback/commit errors.)

title: Address #3173
body:
This is a tricky one. It seems like the behaviour described in that
issue should work out of the box, but it doesn't. I've spend some time
to investigate various solutions to make this work, but I came to the
conclusion that the current behaviour is the correct one.

The underlying issue here is that such an query promotes the inner
`Nullable<_>` of the field onto the outer `Queryable` wrapper. Without
`Selectable` that would require a select clause like
`.select((table::column.assume_not_null(),).nullable())`. This is
technically a safe pattern, but requires the usage of the "advanced"
`assume_not_null()` method to forcibly convert types to their not null representation.

Possible solutions tried to make the enable constructs shown in that
issue:

* I've tried to make the `impl Selectable for Option<T>` return the
following `SelectExpression`:
`dsl::Nullable<dsl::AssumeNotNull<T::SelectExpression>>`
where `AssumeNotNull` converts each tuple element to the corresponding
not nullable expression, while `Nullable` wraps the tuple itself into a
nullable type wrapper.
* I've tried to apply a similar approach like that one above, but only
for derived impls by manipulating the generated code for a optional
field with `#[diesel(embed)]`

Both solutions require changes to our sql type system, as for example
allowing to load a non nullable value into a `Option<T>` to enable their
usage in a more general scope as the presented example case.
(See the added test cases for this). That by itself would be fine in my
opinion, as this is always a safe operation. Unfortunately the
`AssumeNotNull` transformation would be applied recursively for all
sub-tuples, which in turn would cause trouble with nested joins (again
see the examples). We would be able to workaround this issue by allowing
the `FromSql<ST, DB> for Option<T>` impl for non-nullable types to catch
null values, which in turn really feels like a bad hack. (You would like
to get an error there instead, but nested nullable information are
gone.)
All in all this lead me to the conclusion that the current behaviour is
correct.

This PR adds a few additional tests (an adjusted version of the test
from the bug report + more tests around nested joins) and does move
around some code bits that I noticed while working on this.

I think the official answer for the bug report would be: Either wrap the
inner type also in an `Option` or provide a manual `Selectable` impl
that does the "right" thing there.

title: This commit fixes a potential race condition in our r2d2 tests
body:
This was triggered by the fact that the pool tries to open a new
connection after the old one was closed. As this happens in a background
thread this happens concurrently to our test code. That means if
establishing a new connection is fast that will increase the
acquire_count before we checked it. We observed this happening for
sqlite. I've opted into just not checking the acquire count there as
this is not really relevant anyway at that point.

title: Optimise build times
body:
This commit replaces some recursive macros with simpler implementations
by generating non recursive where clauses by just forwarding to the next
smaller impl on the corresponding tuple.
According to my measurements this reduces the build time for a `cargo
check --no-default-features --features "sqlite 64-column-table"` build
from ~1min 20s to ~1min 05s.

title: Fix #3156
body:
Our `R2D2Connection::is_broken` implementations where broken in such a
way that they marked any valid connection as broken as soon as it was
checked into the pool again. This resulted in the pool opening new
connections everytime a connection was checked out of the pool, which
obviously removes the possibility of reusing the same connection again
and again. This commit fixes that issue and adds some tests to ensure
that we do not break this again in the future.

title: Fix potential name collisions in code generated by the `table!` macro
body:
This commit fixes potential name collisions in code generated by the
`table!` macro by prefixing function argument names with
`__diesel_internal`. The underlying problem here is that rust accepts
patterns as part of the function signature. This combined with the fact
that each zero sized struct (so all column/table structs) are type +
value at the same time results in problems as soon as the users tries to
create a column/table with the same name as one of the used arguments.
So for example if the users has a table that contains an `alias` column,
that would have caused a name collision inside of the following function
signature:

```rust
fn map(column: C, alias: &$crate::query_source::Alias<S>) -> Self::Out
```

Rustc would have interpreted `alias` here as zero sized struct literal,
which of course has a different type than the corresponding RHS. That
results in a compiler error about mismatched types.

This commit fixes this problem by prefixing the corresponding variables
with `__diesel_internal`, which is hopefully reasonably uncommon, so
that no one uses that as column name prefix.

title: Make the uuid tests compatible with all supported uuid versions
Add support for slices of refs with BelongingToDsl
body:
See #3138 for discussions.

We cannot add a blanked impl like
```rust
impl<'a, T> Identifiable for &'a &'a T
where
    &'a T: Identifiable
{
    // …
}
```

here as this results in type inference issues with `.belonging_to` and
`.grouped_by`. Rustc tries to infinitely recurse on `&&&&&…&&& T as
Identifiable` then. As of this I've opted into just generating concrete
impls via `#[derive(Identifiable)]` as this works around this type
inference issues.

Also we cannot use a wild card impl for the added `BelongsTo<&Parent>`
case as this causes a conflicting impl error with our
`BelongsTo` impls for tuples. So again we use concrete impls here.


cc #3140 

@valkum Sorry to open this parallel PR, but I had done some experimentation with the blanked `Identifiable` impl and noticed that the code is basically finished at that state of experimentation. So I've just pushed this version.

title: Update dependencies for 2.0
body: This PR updates two outdated dependencies to their newer version. As both are internal to diesel, that does not require any additional work

title: Migration guide draft
body:
This PR adds a first draft of the migration guide for the diesel 2.0 release. I would like to have something in place for a rc release.

[Rendered draft](https://github.com/weiznich/diesel/blob/migration_guide/guide_drafts/migration_guide.md)

Additionally I've put two small other related changes in here:
* Updating the changelog a bit
* Moving `assume_not_nullable` to `NullableExpressionMethods` as that is a better place for it, right next to `nullable()`.

Comments and improvements to the guide are welcome.

(To the other changes as well)

title: ONLY <table> postgres keyword (second attempt)
body:
`Only<S>` (the result of `mytable.only()`) implements `Table`, and only works on `Pg` backend.

I had to add some new macros with long names `__diesel_internal_backend_specific_*`. For example for a postgres-only part of the `allow_tables_to_appear_in_same_query` macro.

title: Bench updates
body:
* Fix the diesel_async benchmarks
* Bump some dependencies
* Use batch inserts for all crates supporting sqlite so that this is a fair benchmark

title: Inline `FromSqlRow::build_from_row` as this function seems to be real…

labels.name: run-benchmarks
labels.description: Used to indicate that github actions should run our benchmark suite

body:
…ly hot

This seems to give up to 5% reduction in instruction count for the
`diesel/trivial_query/1000` benchmarks. Similar improvements are
observed for the boxed query variants.
This change seems to be neutral for the `queryable_by_name` variant.
For the insert/1 benchmark a slight regression in instruction count can
be observed.

title: Bump the diesel_async version to fix the metrics job
Benchmarks with instruction counts

labels.name: run-benchmarks
labels.description: Used to indicate that github actions should run our benchmark suite

body: Hopefully this works also on the CI, otherwise this is only an option for local runs.

title: Make `RawBindCollector` fields public
body:
Otherwise it's not possible to use this bind collector type from a third
party crate (like `diesel_async` or any pure rust mysql/postgres implementation)

title: Improve the doc ci pass
body:
The old version did push a new commit per ci run. Over time that
resulted in a quite large git repository. I've fixed that by manually
removing all revisions for the gh-pages branch + adjusted the workflow
in such a way that it will not create any new commits.

title: Some documentation improvements
body:
This PR adds more cfg attributes to the documentation + fixes a number of links between items.
Additionally it fixes the bin/test script (put that just in here, as it's a minor fix)

title: Enable expressions on the left-hand side of update.set()
body:
It looks like there are a bunch of strategies one can use to implement this behaviour

```
diesel::update(my_table::table).set(array_col.index(1).eq(true))
```

My line of reasoning is -

- There should be a trait between `Column` and `Assign` which `Column` implements which reduces to the current implementation
- This allows the definition of `AssignmentTarget` for arbitrary types which will be picked up by the `AsChangeset` `impl`.

I hit a wall updating the definition for `AsChangeset` as I have an unbounded type parameter (changset.rs:44). I was exploring a few workarounds but none that made me particularly happy.

Would be great to know your thoughts on this direction and whether it's possible to complete this implementation without something heavy like introducing a new param to `AsChangeset`.

title: Missing json operators
body:
This PR adds the missing json/jsonb operators as listed in #3032. It skips the last both operators as they use jsonpath as input type and it's not clear how to represent that on rusts side.

Fixes #3032 
Closes #3044

title: Revert PR #2944 (FROM ONLY <table> clause)
body:
Reverts #2944.
Reason: We need a more general `ONLY` implementation that can be applied to any table, so that we can for example support something along the lines of `.inner_join(my_table.only())` (SQL: `INNER JOIN ONLY my_table`)`

~~I don't know if it got to compile error testing yet, I would expect changes in stderr to have to be committed there because PR #2944 did require that too (due to extra suggestions by the compiler that appeared).~~ Updated compile tests.

title: Add explicit static lifetime to BoxableConnection DB
body:
It seems it is now required.
See issue https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/95028

title: add support for timestamp with timezone for sqlite DB
body:
closes https://github.com/diesel-rs/diesel/issues/2331

# Description

This diff provides support for timestamp with time zone-native Rust objects for the SQLite engine. SQLite fundamentally supports only a few data types so when we format the SQL string for such columns, we do so in the `TEXT` format `"%F %T%.f+00:00"` which provides the added benefit of being lexicographically sortable.

# Testing

`cd diesel && cargo test --no-default-features --features 'extras sqlite'` passes

title: Switch from dotenv to dotenvy
body: Unfortunately dotenv isn't maintained anymore (last commit 2 years ago). That's why [dotenvy](https://github.com/allan2/dotenvy) was created. It's a well maintained fork or the original dotenv.

title: Provide a helper type for `.on`
body:
This is useful when you have a table that you typically want to join on using a very complex clause, and you want to implement a function `on_xxx_and(some_additional_conditions)` on it to make that easy .

I used to use it despite it being doc hidden but now it's fully private.
I think it's reasonable to have that helper type given that `on` is public API.

title: selectable/filterable array.index(n)
body:
@weiznich just want to get your views on this.

A couple of questions I had -

- should I create an `extract_operator!` macro or just define `ArrayIndex` as is in `pg/operators.rs`
- it would be nice to convey 1-indexing to the user, some other way than a doc comment. In Postgres, `foo[-1]` is totally legal though (and accesses a negatively-indexed value, rather than starting from the back e.g. Python).
- The index type should arguably be Nullable<Integer>, or accept both. Would be good to know your thoughts on that.

#1681

title: Add mutable downcast for BoxableConnection
body: This is necessary when doing code based migrations where you need to query the database.

title: Explicitly call `mysql_stmt_free_result` for each executed statement
body: This change adds explicit calls to `mysql_stmt_free_result` for each statement where we have called `mysql_stmt_fetch_result`. This seems to be required according to [the documentation](https://dev.mysql.com/doc/c-api/8.0/en/mysql-stmt-fetch.html) to free internal buffers.

title: Generate Postgres Arrays with Nullable elements by default
body:
It's not possible to enforce non-nullability of Postgres array elements.

The previous behaviour of mapping to `Array<ST>` works fine in practice because Diesel would never _itself_ insert arrays with `NULL` elements. This was at the risk of deserialization errors though, should `NULL` values ever be made present (e.g. by some other process/manually).

title: Allow declaring aliases in separate crates from the schema
body:
The current implementation wouldn't allow declaring aliases downstream from a schema crate: it would result in conflicting impls.

This solves this issue in the same way we solved the conflicting impl issues for tables/Aliases: by using an additional trait dedicated to the impls in the `alias` macro, which downstream crates are allowed to implement (because it's on the alias), and make it so that any implementors of this trait also get the corresponding implementation done (this is done in the `table` macro).

title: Fix alias visibility
body:
Alias declared at the module level would not be visible out of the module due to the lack of "pub".
This fixes it by allowing to specify a visibility modifier in the macro.

Aliases declared with the table-like module-level syntax are always `pub` (like tables).

title: Fix/ci 2022
body: Fixes two out of three failing CI runs

title: add ssl_ca to accepted connection url query params
body:
While #2491 allowed setting ssl_mode in the DATABASE_URL, this is insufficient to successfully initiate an SSL connection in some instances. For example, while running a dockerized service on Debian, the Certificate Authority roots need to be manually set. [See PlanetScale's docs on the subject](https://docs.planetscale.com/concepts/secure-connections#why-do-i-need-to-care-about-a-ca-when-connecting-to-planetscale?)

This adds optional support for `ssl_ca`, following the existing architecture for setting ssl_mode and unix_port in the connection string

Note that I've confirmed this allows for a successful connection to PlanetScale from a debian container

title: Fix clap 3.1 deprecation warnings in Diesel CLI
body:
Those would prevent from compiling at all due to `#![deny(warnings)]`.
Also tests broke due to an error message update.

title: Fix new warning to unbreak CI
Implement jsonb any-key and all-keys check expressions
body: Implemented JSONB  `?|` and `?&` operators.
